Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Application_Facts: Applicant had frequent absences but maintained a home and business in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Alleged failure to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed to Federal Court challenging legal error in assessment of residency
Evidence_Used: Proof of maintained home and business in Canada; travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure by Citizenship Judge to consider overall residency ties beyond physical presence
Decision_Outcome: Original citizenship application denied by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed; case referred back to another Citizenship Judge for reassessment
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application denial
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of residency based on full consideration of residency ties
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation and application of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge erred in law by overemphasizing physical presence and failing to assess pre-existing residency and connections to Canada

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Record of delays, security clearance resolution, application history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 22 – Prohibition on awarding costs absent special reasons
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation in permanent residence application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No special reasons such as unfair, oppressive, or improper conduct by either party
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence that misrepresentations affected judicial proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unfair, oppressive, or bad faith conduct required for cost award
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No costs awarded to either party

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Costs dispute following moot judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether special reasons exist to award costs under Rule 22
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 22 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no costs awarded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentations occurred but no bad faith shown
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Processing timelines, security clearance records, application materials
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 22 – Costs only on special reasons
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Delays due to misrepresentation and administrative inaction
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mutual contribution to delay; absence of improper conduct
Crimes.Application_Error: Inaccurate information provided in residency application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presence of unfair, oppressive, or bad faith behavior
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that false statements impacted fairness of process
Crimes.Legal_Standard: High threshold for cost awards under Rule 22
Crimes.Application_Factor: Combined effect of applicant misrepresentation and ministerial delay
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of misleading information in immigration documents

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the Applicant was not a convention refugee or person in need of protection
Evidence_Type: Alleged past bullying, ethnic tensions in Guyana
Basis_of_Claim: Past bullying and ethnic tensions in Guyana
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence of racially motivated persecution or personalized risk; incident occurred during youth; adequate state protection currently available
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee definition; Person in need of protection
Application_Factor: Personalized risk vs. general country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Upheld Board's rejection of refugee claim

Risk_Assessment: Assessed for general violence, not sexual offending
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of non-sexual violent behavior
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ refusal based on lack of sexual offense conviction deemed reasonable

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of requiring sex offender assessment for PFVs
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of Commissioner’s discretion and statutory alignment
Legal_Rule: Reasonable limits permitted under Act for safety
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of prisoner rights and program participation
Defendant_Response: Denial of PFVs based on non-compliance with assessment

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of right to family visits without just cause
Legal_Framework: Statutory rights and procedural fairness in corrections system
Risk_Factor: Perceived risk based on unconvicted allegations
Credibility: Edwards’ compliance with other programs enhances credibility
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to completed violence program

Risk_Assessment: Low sexual risk, moderate general violence risk
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to assess general risk but not sexual risk
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ position considered credible given voluntary program principles

Evidence_Sufficiency: Strong evidence of violent past, none for sexual misconduct
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ argument supported by statutory principles

Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate to justify concern but not specialized assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ stance aligned with voluntary participation principle
Applicant's position found reasonable
Decision_Rationale: Requirement for sex offender assessment not justified without sexual offense conviction
Authority_Responsible: Commissioner of Correctional Service of Canada

Application_Facts: Applicant claims she will face persecution from former traffickers if returned to Romania due to inadequate state protection.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer erred by relying on Romania's efforts rather than its effectiveness.
Evidence_Used: Evidence shows corruption, recapture risks, and insufficient police capability.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer relied on insufficient evidence of effective state protection.
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed until judicial review application is resolved.
Outcome: Stay of removal granted pending judicial review.
Remedy_Sought: Protection from deportation due to risk of harm
Legal_Standard_Applied: State protection requires both the will and capacity of the government to effectively implement legislation and programs to protect victims.
Standard_of_Review: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has raised a serious issue, faces irreparable harm, and the balance of convenience favors granting a stay of removal.

Criminality_Severity: High – risk of retribution and sexual exploitation
Risk_Nature: Targeted harm by non-state actors due to prior exploitation
Evidence_Credibility: Credible based on consistency and corroboration
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims found credible

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Inadequate state protection for trafficking victims
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97(1) IRPA – Danger to life, liberty, or cruel treatment
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution due to ineffective state protection
Legal_Framework: International human rights law, domestic refugee protection framework
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed pending judicial review
Targeted_Group: Trafficking survivors returning to home country
State_Protection_Assessment: Romanian state lacks capacity due to corruption and weak enforcement
Legal_Provision: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate – lack of will and capacity
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with state complicity or neglect
Perpetrator_Entity: Human traffickers, potentially aided by corrupt officials

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess state protection
Application_Facts: PRRA Officer ignored evidence of corruption and specific threats; focused on formal measures over actual protection
Procedural_Issue: Error in applying legal standard for state protection
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to review PRRA decisions
Evidence_Used: Evidence of police corruption, inadequate response, and personal threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer failed to consider key evidence on effectiveness of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims treated as credible by the court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant demonstrated serious issue regarding state protection, risk of irreparable harm, and favorable balance of convenience

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Modupe is inadmissible for misrepresentation under IRPA s. 40(1)(a) without knowledge of the false information
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Modupe's affidavit stating lack of knowledge was unchallenged and accepted
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of birth certificate listing Cladius as father despite non-biological relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Assuming intent to misrepresent without proof of knowledge
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Modupe’s credible explanation and lack of intent
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Knowingly misstating or withholding material facts
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on official document without verifying biological parentage
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incorrect birth certificate used, but not knowingly

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Modupe misrepresented material facts about Olakunle's paternity without knowledge
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Modupe’s belief in Cladius being the father deemed credible; disclosure of separation noted
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inclusion of Cladius as father on application based on official documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of intent to deceive; reliance on legal document and honest belief
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider applicant’s lack of knowledge and good faith
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Context of brief separation and reasonable belief in paternity
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Knowingly misrepresenting material facts under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of legally issued birth certificate reflecting presumed fatherhood
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Erroneous information submitted via birth certificate, no fraudulent intent found

Application_Facts: Applicants sought refugee protection after alleged persecution by FARC in Colombia
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to make clear findings on father's kidnapping and applicant's subjective fear
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Uncertainty regarding father's kidnapping, lack of clarity on credibility grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility findings questioned due to applicant's inaction in the U.S. and lack of clear findings on fear and kidnapping
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings were unreasonable due to insufficient justification and unclear conclusions

Crimes.Crime_Name: False representations or fraud in obtaining citizenship
Legal_Issue: Does Section 7 of the Charter apply to protect Fast's rights during citizenship revocation proceedings?
Governing_Law: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Credibility_Assessment: Fast suffers from dementia, impairing his ability to participate meaningfully
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false representations regarding WWII-related activities
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Binding precedent that Section 7 does not apply to revocation proceedings
Legal_Standard: Section 7 protections (life, liberty, security of the person) do not apply in civil revocation proceedings per precedent
Application_Factor: Defendant's mental capacity due to dementia

Crimes.Crime_Name: Concealment of material circumstances in obtaining citizenship
Violation_Type: Concealment of material facts related to WWII activities
Governing_Law: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Fast allegedly concealed involvement in wartime activities
Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose material information during citizenship application
Procedural_Issue: Impact of dementia on ability to defend oneself
Evidence_Used: Medical reports, legal precedents, historical evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Severe dementia affects participation but not deemed sufficient to trigger Section 7
Relief_Sought: Stay of proceedings based on Charter rights
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of revocation process due to incapacity
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 7 inapplicable in citizenship revocation as per binding precedent
Standard_of_Review: Deference to existing Federal Court rulings
Decision_Rationale: Court bound by precedent despite sympathy for applicant's condition

Mitigating_Factors: Diminished influence of Atyanski after prosecution
Criminality_Severity: High due to organized criminal network
Risk_Assessment: Well-founded fear assessed but found not objectively valid
Risk_Nature: Targeted due to personal conflict with powerful figure
Evidence_Type: Testimony, country condition reports, prosecution records
Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible but outweighed by state action evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Claim deemed plausible but not supported by current conditions

Legal_Issue: Well-founded fear of persecution
Evidence_Assessment: RPD evaluated threats and state protection mechanisms
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to prove well-founded fear
Credibility_Factor: Claimant's testimony weighed against country condition evidence
Legal_Rule: Convention refugee status requires objective threat despite state protection
Key_Evidence_Considered: Atyanski’s conviction, reduced influence, state protection availability
Defendant_Response: State demonstrated capacity to protect through prosecutors
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, legal proceedings, expert reports

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection based on systemic corruption
Legal_Issue: Existence of effective state protection despite past police corruption
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed efforts to address police corruption
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to show lack of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Concerns about corruption balanced by institutional reforms
Legal_Rule: Changed country conditions may negate need for protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Harassment linked to corrupt police elements
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prosecution of Atyanski, role of public prosecutors
Evidence_Type: Country reports, judicial decisions, institutional reform data

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim linked to financial crimes by public official
Legal_Issue: Whether conviction for bankruptcy-related offences eliminated threat
Evidence_Assessment: Atyanski’s conviction reduced his power and reach
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to demonstrate ongoing risk
Credibility_Factor: Link between financial crime and continued threat questioned
Legal_Rule: Changed circumstances can negate well-founded fear
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution following conflict with MP involved in financial crimes
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction record, loss of political immunity, state actions
Evidence_Type: Court records, parliamentary proceedings, enforcement actions

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection due to state-linked corruption
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to powerful corrupt figure
Targeted_Group: Individual targeted due to personal conflict
State_Protection_Assessment: Available and effective through non-police actors
Risk_Factor: Past abuse of power, diminished current threat
Credibility: Plausible past events, but current risk not established

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on organized criminal threats
Legal_Issue: Ongoing threat from criminal organization after leader's conviction
Evidence_Assessment: No sufficient proof of continued operations or threat

Credibility_Factor: Past harassment acknowledged but not current danger
Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear must be current and substantiated
Grounds_for_Claim: Harassment by associates of convicted MP
Defendant_Response: State capable of countering organized crime

Dispute_Type: Patent validity and infringement under regulatory framework
Legal_Issue: Whether Genpharm's manufacturing and selling of citalopram infringes Lundbeck's '368 patent
Procedural_Stage: Application to prohibit issuance of Notice of Compliance
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence showed citalopram is used for depression, with insufficient proof of use in dementia or cerebrovascular disorders
Burden_of_Proof: On generic manufacturer to prove non-infringement under PM (NOC) Regulations
Credibility_Factor: Credibility of expert evidence on medical uses of citalopram
Legal_Rule: Generic must prove non-infringement of listed patents; court evaluates justification based on evidence
Standard_of_Review: Justification of allegations based on evidentiary record
Grounds_for_Claim: Lundbeck claimed potential use overlap in dementia/CVD treatment
Outcome_on_Merits: Genpharm's allegation of non-infringement was justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical evidence on approved and intended use of citalopram
Legal_Framework: Regulatory approval process under PM (NOC) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Genpharm limited indication to depression and denied intent to treat patented conditions
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony, product labeling, clinical data
Remedy_Requested: Injunction to prevent Health Canada from issuing Notice of Compliance
Outcome: Application denied; Genpharm allowed to proceed
Legal_Provision: Section under PM (NOC) Regulations regarding patent listing and certification

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal charge under section 264.1(1)(a) of the Criminal Code
Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction to remove Councillor
Procedural fairness
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of accepted Band custom
Legal_Rule: Removal must be authorized by Code or accepted Band custom
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of Code provision for removal
Policy limits removal to Portfolio only

Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether the Officer exercised proper discretion in forfeiting a cash bond after a perceived breach of immigration release conditions
Legal_Issue: Did the Officer properly exercise discretion in forfeiting the cash bond?
Evidence_Assessment: Marginal notes indicate consideration of submissions, but reasons for differential treatment are unclear
Decision_Outcome: Forfeiture decision remitted to a different Officer for redetermination due to lack of clarity in reasoning
Legal_Rule: Officers have discretion to forfeit bonds based on case merits. Decisions must be made in good faith, following natural justice principles, without irrelevant considerations.
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of clear reasoning for differential treatment between cash bond and performance bond forfeiture
Key_Evidence_Considered: Submissions from parties, breach of release conditions
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, principles of natural justice
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, marginal notes, legal arguments
Remedy_Requested: Redetermination of forfeiture decision by a different Officer with clearer reasoning
Authority: Immigration Officer (decision under review), Federal Court (reviewing authority)

Crime_Name: Unreasonable Delay in Processing Permanent Residence Application
Legal_Issue: Whether a writ of mandamus is justified due to unreasonable delay in processing a permanent residence application
Evidence_Assessment: Application submitted in 1994; delays until 2003 due to legitimate processes; post-2003 delays included medical, criminal, and security checks; 1.5 years of unaccounted delay not deemed unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonable delay and lack of alternative remedy
Credibility_Factor: Applicant recognized as a Convention refugee, but no evidence of bad faith or intentional delay by authorities
Legal_Rule: Mandamus is granted if there is a public legal duty owed to the applicant, no other adequate remedy, and the delay is unreasonable
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonable delay in processing permanent residence application after refugee status recognition
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; court found delay was not unreasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of application (1994), timeline of processing, reasons for delay (medical, criminal, security checks), duration of unexplained delay (1.5 years)
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, principles of mandamus, immigration regulations
Defendant_Response: Delays were attributable to necessary background checks and administrative procedures
Remedy_Requested: Writ of mandamus to compel processing of permanent residence application
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Federal Court Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. F-7

Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies Noted
Gender Guidelines Not Properly Applied

Legal_Issue: Can an interlocutory injunction be dissolved due to delay or change of circumstances in a trademark dispute?
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence of confusion between trademarks contradicts Office Depot's claim that confusion no longer exists
Decision_Outcome: Application to dissolve the interlocutory injunction is denied
Burden_of_Proof: Office Depot failed to prove substantial changes in circumstances
Legal_Rule: An interlocutory injunction can be dissolved if there is significant delay or if circumstances have changed so drastically that the original order's basis is no longer valid.
Outcome_on_Merits: Court dismissed the application; parties ordered to expedite trial preparations
Defendant_Response: Office Depot filed a motion to dissolve the injunction
Evidence_Type: Testimonial or documentary evidence on confusion

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of hardship assessment under H&C grounds
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's ability to adapt, EU membership, lack of cumulative impact evidence, Roma discrimination in home country
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate sufficient hardship
Credibility_Factor: Lack of personal experiences of discrimination in Ireland
Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship due to potential return to country of origin
Key_Evidence_Considered: EU membership, integration in Canada, absence of personal risk evidence in Ireland
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds provisions under IRPA
Defendant_Response: Officer provided transparent and justifiable reasons for refusal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Employment discrimination and failure to address harassment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing the complaint under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RCMP's failure to act after substantiating the complaint occurred within one year of filing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to show timely basis for complaint; Commission must justify dismissal
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Complaint based on documented harassment and institutional inaction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Complaints must relate to acts or omissions within one year unless extended
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Sexual harassment by superior and employer's failure to take remedial action
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of RCMP’s inaction relative to complaint filing
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law and human rights law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RCMP did not discipline the superior or implement corrective measures
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and procedural record of internal investigation and response
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of complaint by the Commission
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remanded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Workplace sexual harassment and institutional failure to respond
Crimes.Application_Facts: Alleged harassment by Chief Superintendent Soave and RCMP's failure to act post-investigation
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Constable Sharon Thompson, serving member of RCMP
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Dismissal of complaint based on time limitation grounds without full investigation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Canadian Human Rights Commission over internal RCMP conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Timeline of harassment incidents and subsequent inaction by RCMP
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Commission failed to assess timeliness of employer’s inaction
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Complaint supported by internal investigation findings
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; matter remitted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reconsideration of the complaint by the Commission
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for the Commission to reassess the complaint on its merits
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RCMP’s failure to act occurred within one-year window, making complaint timely

Dispute_Type: Immigration status and eligibility for permanent residence
Legal_Issue: Whether legal adoption under foreign law automatically establishes a parent-child relationship for Canadian immigration purposes
Evidence_Assessment: Tribunal assessed legality of Philippine adoption but did not assess existence of genuine parent-child relationship
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside; case remanded for redetermination
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate genuine parent-child relationship
Legal_Rule: Adoption must comply with foreign law and create a genuine parent-child relationship under Canadian immigration law
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of 'no objection' letter, insufficient humanitarian grounds, misinterpretation of regulations
Outcome_on_Merits: Application initially allowed by tribunal, then overturned on review
Key_Evidence_Considered: Legality of Philippine adoption, absence of factual parent-child relationship analysis
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, specifically adoption provisions in Immigration Regulations
Defendant_Response: Minister challenged tribunal's decision on grounds of legal error
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (adoption documents), procedural compliance records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside tribunal's decision
Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside, case referred back to Immigration and Refugee Board
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Legal_Issue: Whether the High Commission erred in using the applicant's last-known email address for communication
Governing_Law: Immigration rules and principles of administrative fairness
Evidence_Assessment: Email sent to last known address; no confirmation of delivery failure
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to update contact information
Legal_Rule: Immigration officials fulfill duty by sending notices to valid, unrevoked addresses; risk of non-receipt lies with applicant if address not updated
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged communication failure due to undelivered email
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of last-known email address provided by representative
Defendant_Response: Communication was properly sent; applicant responsible for outdated contact details
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa refusal decision

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute over pharmaceutical product (lisinopril)
Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex can claim noninfringement under s. 56 of the Patent Act to avoid prohibition of NOC issuance
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Apotex acquired lisinopril before the '350 patent but not before the '351 patent's novel use was patented
Decision_Outcome: Prohibition of NOC issuance to Apotex until expiration of both the '350 and '351 patents
Burden_of_Proof: On Zeneca to demonstrate potential infringement and on Apotex to justify immunity under s. 56
Legal_Rule: s. 56 of the Patent Act provides immunity from liability for acts prior to patent grant but does not establish noninfringement; applies only to composition patents, not new uses
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review context
Grounds_for_Claim: Infringement of the '351 patent covering a novel use of lisinopril
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex cannot rely on s. 56 for the '351 patent; prohibition order upheld
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of Apotex’s acquisition of lisinopril relative to the grant dates of the '350 and '351 patents
Legal_Framework: Patent Act, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Apotex claimed noninfringement under s. 56 of the Patent Act
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of patent grants, product development timelines
Remedy_Requested: Prevention of NOC issuance to Apotex
Outcome: Court prohibited Minister from issuing NOC to Apotex until both patents expire
Authority: Federal Court under judicial review powers

Legal_Issue: Whether the Pension Appeal Board fulfilled its legal duties in granting leave to appeal
Evidence_Assessment: Ms. Carroll's application lacked required details and evidence
Decision_Outcome: PAB's decision overturned due to procedural failures
Legal_Rule: PAB must record decisions in writing, provide reasons if application lacks grounds, and apply correct test for leave
Grounds_for_Claim: Incomplete application and failure by PAB to follow procedural requirements
Outcome_on_Merits: PAB must reconsider the appeal request
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of written decision, lack of reasoning, no indication of test applied
Outcome: PAB must reconsider granting leave to appeal with proper procedures
